title: This year's 3-0 start has more optimistic feel than last year's
text:
This year's 3-0 start has more optimistic feel than last year's 
Updated: Fri, Oct 02 2015, 01:30 AM 
CINCINNATI (Richard Skinner) -- A 3-0 record is a 3-0 record, except when it feels different, and this year's 3-0 record for the Bengals to start this season feels a lot different than the 3-0 record it had to start last season. 
It has a more optimistic feel to it. 
That feeling comes despite the fact that just like last season the Bengals won a tough road game at Baltimore, and that they outscored their first three opponents last season by a combined 47 points compared to outscoring the first three this season by a combined 29 points. 
Maybe it comes from the fact that the season-opening win in Oakland looks a lot better after the Raiders won their next two games. 
Maybe it comes from the fact that the two teams the Bengals beat outside of Baltimore to start last season (Atlanta and Tennessee) combined to finish with an 8-24 record. 
I think it comes from the fact that unlike three games into last season, this year's team is almost fully healthy (outside of safety George Iloka battling an ankle issue and linebacker Vontaze Burfict missing the first six games after being placed on the Physically Unable to Perform list to open the season) and gets to continue playing instead of taking an early bye like last season. Then, the first game following that bye the Bengals played at New England the first game after it lost in embarrassing fashion at Kansas City and was basically written off as being finished. 
Some of the players think the same thing. 
"Last year they put us on ice with it being a bye week right after that 3-0, and the Patriots had the game they had, so they came out heated," said defensive end Carlos Dunlap. "Fortunately we don’t have that bye week and we’re still hot right now." 
Said running back Giovani Bernard: "The early bye might not have been the best thing. The guys are walking around with a little more swagger, a little more confidence. Confidence is a huge thing for an offense and for the team. It’s all about injuries and what team stays the healthiest, and we’re doing a really good of staying heathy. At the end the day, the teams that stay the healthiest go the farthest." 
Said quarterback Andy Dalton: "I think when everybody looks at the schedule and you have a Week 4 bye, it's not ideal. We are in a rhythm right now, we are in a good routine, and it's nice that we just get to keep going with it.” 
The Bengals will try for just the fourth 4-0 start in franchise history on Sunday when they host the Chiefs in Paul Brown Stadium. 
It won't be an easy game, because the Chiefs have enough talent to make the playoffs, and because it's a classic trap game as it comes after the emotional divisional win at Baltimore and with two-time defending NFC champion Seattle coming up next week in Paul Brown Stadium. 
"We feel like we've got the right mentality, and so we've got to do whatever it takes to not let anything slip," said Dalton. "I think it’s just the way that we're being coached. I think that our mindset is, we're not satisfied with where we are. It's only three games into the season; we're on our fourth game. That's the attitude you have to have.” 
The other three times the Bengals began the season 4-0 they made the playoffs each time (1975, 1988 when they went to the Super Bowl and 2005), but just making the playoffs isn't the goal. They've done that the last four years without a 4-0 start. 
But, it's getting harder and harder to find any weakness on this team when it's this healthy and it will likely gets it best defensive player (Burfict) back after this year's bye week when they face the Steelers in game No. 7 on Nov. 1. 
Perhaps that's why this year's 3-0 has a more optimistic feel to it than last year's 3-0.
